text: The vision concerning Judah and Jerusalem that Isaiah son of Amoz saw during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear me, you heavens! Listen, earth!
    For the Lord has spoken:
“I reared children and brought them up,
    but they have rebelled against me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ox knows its master,
    the donkey its owner’s manger,
but Israel does not know,
    my people do not understand.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the sinful nation,
    a people whose guilt is great,
a brood of evildoers,
    children given to corruption!
They have forsaken the Lord;
    they have spurned the Holy One of Israel
    and turned their backs on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should you be beaten anymore?
    Why do you persist in rebellion?
Your whole head is injured,
    your whole heart afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the sole of your foot to the top of your head
    there is no soundness—
only wounds and welts
    and open sores,
not cleansed or bandaged
    or soothed with olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your country is desolate,
    your cities burned with fire;
your fields are being stripped by foreigners
    right before you,
    laid waste as when overthrown by strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Daughter Zion is left
    like a shelter in a vineyard,
like a hut in a cucumber field,
    like a city under siege.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Unless the Lord Almighty
    had left us some survivors,
we would have become like Sodom,
    we would have been like Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear the word of the Lord,
    you rulers of Sodom;
listen to the instruction of our God,
    you people of Gomorrah!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The multitude of your sacrifices—
    what are they to me?” says the Lord.
“I have more than enough of burnt offerings,
    of rams and the fat of fattened animals;
I have no pleasure
    in the blood of bulls and lambs and goats.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you come to appear before me,
    who has asked this of you,
    this trampling of my courts?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stop bringing meaningless offerings!
    Your incense is detestable to me.
New Moons, Sabbaths and convocations—
    I cannot bear your worthless assemblies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your New Moon feasts and your appointed festivals
    I hate with all my being.
They have become a burden to me;
    I am weary of bearing them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you spread out your hands in prayer,
    I hide my eyes from you;
even when you offer many prayers,
    I am not listening.
Your hands are full of blood!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Learn to do right; seek justice.
    Defend the oppressed.
Take up the cause of the fatherless;
    plead the case of the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come now, let us settle the matter,”
    says the Lord.
“Though your sins are like scarlet,
    they shall be as white as snow;
though they are red as crimson,
    they shall be like wool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are willing and obedient,
    you will eat the good things of the land;
speaker: Narrator

text:
but if you resist and rebel,
    you will be devoured by the sword.”
For the mouth of the Lord has spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
See how the faithful city
    has become a prostitute!
She once was full of justice;
    righteousness used to dwell in her—
    but now murderers!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your silver has become dross,
    your choice wine is diluted with water.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord, the Lord Almighty,
    the Mighty One of Israel, declares:
“Ah! I will vent my wrath on my foes
    and avenge myself on my enemies.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
I will restore your leaders as in days of old,
    your rulers as at the beginning.
Afterward you will be called
    the City of Righteousness,
    the Faithful City.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zion will be delivered with justice,
    her penitent ones with righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But rebels and sinners will both be broken,
    and those who forsake the Lord will perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You will be ashamed because of the sacred oaks
    in which you have delighted;
you will be disgraced because of the gardens
    that you have chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be like an oak with fading leaves,
    like a garden without water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mighty man will become tinder
    and his work a spark;
both will burn together,
    with no one to quench the fire.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is what Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the last days
the mountain of the Lord’s temple will be established
    as the highest of the mountains;
it will be exalted above the hills,
    and all nations will stream to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many peoples will come and say,
“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,
    to the temple of the God of Jacob.
He will teach us his ways,
    so that we may walk in his paths.”
The law will go out from Zion,
    the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will judge between the nations
    and will settle disputes for many peoples.
They will beat their swords into plowshares
    and their spears into pruning hooks.
Nation will not take up sword against nation,
    nor will they train for war anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, descendants of Jacob,
    let us walk in the light of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You, Lord, have abandoned your people,
    the descendants of Jacob.
They are full of superstitions from the East;
    they practice divination like the Philistines
    and embrace pagan customs.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator
Narrator

text:
So people will be brought low
    and everyone humbled—
    do not forgive them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go into the rocks, hide in the ground
    from the fearful presence of the Lord
    and the splendor of his majesty!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The Lord Almighty has a day in store
    for all the proud and lofty,
for all that is exalted
    (and they will be humbled),
speaker: Narrator

text:
for all the cedars of Lebanon, tall and lofty,
    and all the oaks of Bashan,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for all the towering mountains
    and all the high hills,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for every lofty tower
    and every fortified wall,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for every trading ship
    and every stately vessel.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: and the idols will totally disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will flee to caves in the rocks
    and to holes in the ground
from the fearful presence of the Lord
    and the splendor of his majesty,
    when he rises to shake the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day people will throw away
    to the moles and bats
their idols of silver and idols of gold,
    which they made to worship.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They will flee to caverns in the rocks
    and to the overhanging crags
from the fearful presence of the Lord
    and the splendor of his majesty,
    when he rises to shake the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Stop trusting in mere humans,
    who have but a breath in their nostrils.
    Why hold them in esteem?
speaker: Narrator

text:
See now, the Lord,
    the Lord Almighty,
is about to take from Jerusalem and Judah
    both supply and support:
all supplies of food and all supplies of water,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the hero and the warrior,
the judge and the prophet,
    the diviner and the elder,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the captain of fifty and the man of rank,
    the counselor, skilled craftsman and clever enchanter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will make mere youths their officials;
    children will rule over them.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
People will oppress each other—
    man against man, neighbor against neighbor.
The young will rise up against the old,
    the nobody against the honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A man will seize one of his brothers
    in his father’s house, and say,
“You have a cloak, you be our leader;
    take charge of this heap of ruins!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But in that day he will cry out,
    “I have no remedy.
I have no food or clothing in my house;
    do not make me the leader of the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jerusalem staggers,
    Judah is falling;
their words and deeds are against the Lord,
    defying his glorious presence.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Tell the righteous it will be well with them,
    for they will enjoy the fruit of their deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to the wicked!
    Disaster is upon them!
They will be paid back
    for what their hands have done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Youths oppress my people,
    women rule over them.
My people, your guides lead you astray;
    they turn you from the path.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord takes his place in court;
    he rises to judge the people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord enters into judgment
    against the elders and leaders of his people:
“It is you who have ruined my vineyard;
    the plunder from the poor is in your houses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What do you mean by crushing my people
    and grinding the faces of the poor?”
declares the Lord, the Lord Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord says,
    “The women of Zion are haughty,
walking along with outstretched necks,
    flirting with their eyes,
strutting along with swaying hips,
    with ornaments jingling on their ankles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord will bring sores on the heads of the women of Zion;
    the Lord will make their scalps bald.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Lord will snatch away their finery: the bangles and headbands and crescent necklaces,
speaker: Narrator

text: the earrings and bracelets and veils,
speaker: Narrator

text: the headdresses and anklets and sashes, the perfume bottles and charms,
speaker: Narrator

text: the signet rings and nose rings,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fine robes and the capes and cloaks, the purses
speaker: Narrator

text: and mirrors, and the linen garments and tiaras and shawls.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Your men will fall by the sword,
    your warriors in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The gates of Zion will lament and mourn;
    destitute, she will sit on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day seven women
    will take hold of one man
and say, “We will eat our own food
    and provide our own clothes;
only let us be called by your name.
    Take away our disgrace!”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land will be the pride and glory of the survivors in Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who are left in Zion, who remain in Jerusalem, will be called holy, all who are recorded among the living in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will wash away the filth of the women of Zion; he will cleanse the bloodstains from Jerusalem by a spirit of judgment and a spirit of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord will create over all of Mount Zion and over those who assemble there a cloud of smoke by day and a glow of flaming fire by night; over everything the glory will be a canopy.
speaker: Narrator

text: It will be a shelter and shade from the heat of the day, and a refuge and hiding place from the storm and rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will sing for the one I love
    a song about his vineyard:
My loved one had a vineyard
    on a fertile hillside.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He dug it up and cleared it of stones
    and planted it with the choicest vines.
He built a watchtower in it
    and cut out a winepress as well.
Then he looked for a crop of good grapes,
    but it yielded only bad fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Now you dwellers in Jerusalem and people of Judah,
    judge between me and my vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What more could have been done for my vineyard
    than I have done for it?
When I looked for good grapes,
    why did it yield only bad?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I will tell you
    what I am going to do to my vineyard:
I will take away its hedge,
    and it will be destroyed;
I will break down its wall,
    and it will be trampled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will make it a wasteland,
    neither pruned nor cultivated,
    and briers and thorns will grow there.
I will command the clouds
    not to rain on it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The vineyard of the Lord Almighty
    is the nation of Israel,
and the people of Judah
    are the vines he delighted in.
And he looked for justice, but saw bloodshed;
    for righteousness, but heard cries of distress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you who add house to house
    and join field to field
till no space is left
    and you live alone in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord Almighty has declared in my hearing:
“Surely the great houses will become desolate,
    the fine mansions left without occupants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A ten-acre vineyard will produce only a bath of wine;
    a homer of seed will yield only an ephah of grain.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who rise early in the morning
    to run after their drinks,
who stay up late at night
    till they are inflamed with wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have harps and lyres at their banquets,
    pipes and timbrels and wine,
but they have no regard for the deeds of the Lord,
    no respect for the work of his hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore my people will go into exile
    for lack of understanding;
those of high rank will die of hunger
    and the common people will be parched with thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore Death expands its jaws,
    opening wide its mouth;
into it will descend their nobles and masses
    with all their brawlers and revelers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So people will be brought low
    and everyone humbled,
    the eyes of the arrogant humbled.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the Lord Almighty will be exalted by his justice,
    and the holy God will be proved holy by his righteous acts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then sheep will graze as in their own pasture;
    lambs will feed among the ruins of the rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who draw sin along with cords of deceit,
    and wickedness as with cart ropes,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Woe to those who call evil good
    and good evil,
who put darkness for light
    and light for darkness,
who put bitter for sweet
    and sweet for bitter.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes
    and clever in their own sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to those who are heroes at drinking wine
    and champions at mixing drinks,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who acquit the guilty for a bribe,
    but deny justice to the innocent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore, as tongues of fire lick up straw
    and as dry grass sinks down in the flames,
so their roots will decay
    and their flowers blow away like dust;
for they have rejected the law of the Lord Almighty
    and spurned the word of the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore the Lord’s anger burns against his people;
    his hand is raised and he strikes them down.
The mountains shake,
    and the dead bodies are like refuse in the streets.
Yet for all this, his anger is not turned away,
    his hand is still upraised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He lifts up a banner for the distant nations,
    he whistles for those at the ends of the earth.
Here they come,
    swiftly and speedily!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Not one of them grows tired or stumbles,
    not one slumbers or sleeps;
not a belt is loosened at the waist,
    not a sandal strap is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their arrows are sharp,
    all their bows are strung;
their horses’ hooves seem like flint,
    their chariot wheels like a whirlwind.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their roar is like that of the lion,
    they roar like young lions;
they growl as they seize their prey
    and carry it off with no one to rescue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In that day they will roar over it
    like the roaring of the sea.
And if one looks at the land,
    there is only darkness and distress;
    even the sun will be darkened by clouds.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: At the sound of their voices the doorposts and thresholds shook and the temple was filled with smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to me!” I cried. “I am ruined! For I am a man of unclean lips, and I live among a people of unclean lips, and my eyes have seen the King, the Lord Almighty.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then one of the seraphim flew to me with a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with tongs from the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: With it he touched my mouth and said, “See, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away and your sin atoned for.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send? And who will go for us?”
And I said, “Here am I. Send me!”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Make the heart of this people calloused;
    make their ears dull
    and close their eyes.
Otherwise they might see with their eyes,
    hear with their ears,
    understand with their hearts,
and turn and be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I said, “For how long, Lord?”
And he answered:
“Until the cities lie ruined
    and without inhabitant,
until the houses are left deserted
    and the fields ruined and ravaged,
speaker: Narrator

text:
until the Lord has sent everyone far away
    and the land is utterly forsaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And though a tenth remains in the land,
    it will again be laid waste.
But as the terebinth and oak
    leave stumps when they are cut down,
    so the holy seed will be the stump in the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahaz son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, was king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel marched up to fight against Jerusalem, but they could not overpower it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the house of David was told, “Aram has allied itself with Ephraim”; so the hearts of Ahaz and his people were shaken, as the trees of the forest are shaken by the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out, you and your son Shear-Jashub, to meet Ahaz at the end of the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, on the road to the Launderer’s Field.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say to him, ‘Be careful, keep calm and don’t be afraid. Do not lose heart because of these two smoldering stubs of firewood—because of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and of the son of Remaliah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Aram, Ephraim and Remaliah’s son have plotted your ruin, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let us invade Judah; let us tear it apart and divide it among ourselves, and make the son of Tabeel king over it.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet this is what the Sovereign Lord says:
“‘It will not take place,
    it will not happen,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the head of Aram is Damascus,
    and the head of Damascus is only Rezin.
Within sixty-five years
    Ephraim will be too shattered to be a people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The head of Ephraim is Samaria,
    and the head of Samaria is only Remaliah’s son.
If you do not stand firm in your faith,
    you will not stand at all.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Again the Lord spoke to Ahaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask the Lord your God for a sign, whether in the deepest depths or in the highest heights.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask; I will not put the Lord to the test.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Isaiah said, “Hear now, you house of David! Is it not enough to try the patience of humans? Will you try the patience of my God also?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign: The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and will call him Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will be eating curds and honey when he knows enough to reject the wrong and choose the right,
speaker: Narrator

text: for before the boy knows enough to reject the wrong and choose the right, the land of the two kings you dread will be laid waste.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will bring on you and on your people and on the house of your father a time unlike any since Ephraim broke away from Judah—he will bring the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Lord will whistle for flies from the Nile delta in Egypt and for bees from the land of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: They will all come and settle in the steep ravines and in the crevices in the rocks, on all the thornbushes and at all the water holes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Lord will use a razor hired from beyond the Euphrates River—the king of Assyria—to shave your head and private parts, and to cut off your beard also.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day, a person will keep alive a young cow and two goats.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because of the abundance of the milk they give, there will be curds to eat. All who remain in the land will eat curds and honey.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day, in every place where there were a thousand vines worth a thousand silver shekels, there will be only briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hunters will go there with bow and arrow, for the land will be covered with briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for all the hills once cultivated by the hoe, you will no longer go there for fear of the briers and thorns; they will become places where cattle are turned loose and where sheep run.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to me, “Take a large scroll and write on it with an ordinary pen: Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So I called in Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberekiah as reliable witnesses for me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I made love to the prophetess, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. And the Lord said to me, “Name him Maher-Shalal-Hash-Baz.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the boy knows how to say ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the plunder of Samaria will be carried off by the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to me again:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Because this people has rejected
    the gently flowing waters of Shiloah
and rejoices over Rezin
    and the son of Remaliah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore the Lord is about to bring against them
    the mighty floodwaters of the Euphrates—
    the king of Assyria with all his pomp.
It will overflow all its channels,
    run over all its banks
speaker: Narrator

text:
and sweep on into Judah, swirling over it,
    passing through it and reaching up to the neck.
Its outspread wings will cover the breadth of your land,
    Immanuel!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Raise the war cry, you nations, and be shattered!
    Listen, all you distant lands.
Prepare for battle, and be shattered!
    Prepare for battle, and be shattered!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: This is what the Lord says to me with his strong hand upon me, warning me not to follow the way of this people:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do not call conspiracy
    everything this people calls a conspiracy;
do not fear what they fear,
    and do not dread it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord Almighty is the one you are to regard as holy,
    he is the one you are to fear,
    he is the one you are to dread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will be a holy place;
    for both Israel and Judah he will be
a stone that causes people to stumble
    and a rock that makes them fall.
And for the people of Jerusalem he will be
    a trap and a snare.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Bind up this testimony of warning
    and seal up God’s instruction among my disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will wait for the Lord,
    who is hiding his face from the descendants of Jacob.
I will put my trust in him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here am I, and the children the Lord has given me. We are signs and symbols in Israel from the Lord Almighty, who dwells on Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: When someone tells you to consult mediums and spiritists, who whisper and mutter, should not a people inquire of their God? Why consult the dead on behalf of the living?
speaker: Narrator

text: Consult God’s instruction and the testimony of warning. If anyone does not speak according to this word, they have no light of dawn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Distressed and hungry, they will roam through the land; when they are famished, they will become enraged and, looking upward, will curse their king and their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they will look toward the earth and see only distress and darkness and fearful gloom, and they will be thrust into utter darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, there will be no more gloom for those who were in distress. In the past he humbled the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the future he will honor Galilee of the nations, by the Way of the Sea, beyond the Jordan—
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people walking in darkness
    have seen a great light;
on those living in the land of deep darkness
    a light has dawned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You have enlarged the nation
    and increased their joy;
they rejoice before you
    as people rejoice at the harvest,
as warriors rejoice
    when dividing the plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For as in the day of Midian’s defeat,
    you have shattered
the yoke that burdens them,
    the bar across their shoulders,
    the rod of their oppressor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every warrior’s boot used in battle
    and every garment rolled in blood
will be destined for burning,

speaker: Narrator

text:

text:
